title: Conman who fleeced Lottery out of £2,500,000 jackpot jailed for 9 years
text:
Edward Putman (left) was sentenced to 9 years for using a fake lottery ticket. He had been working with Giles Knibbs (right) to pull off the scam (Picture: PA)

A conman has been sentenced to nine years in jail for using a fake Lottery ticket to cash in an unclaimed £2.5 million jackpot.

Edward Putman, 54, conspired with a Camelot insider to swindle the system and present a counterfeit slip to land the outstanding top prize in 2009.

His co-conspirator Giles Knibbs worked in the securities department at the Lottery operator.

Their fraud fell apart when Knibbs confessed to a friend before killing himself.

Jurors at St Albans Crown Court found Putman guilty of fraud by false representation on Friday after a two-week trial.

Putman, 54, has been jailed at St Albans Crown Court for nine years for cashing in a fake National Lottery ticket (Picture: PA)

Convicted rapist and benefits cheat Putman, 54, of Kings Langley, Hertfordshire, wore a Barbour-style jacket and blue jeans and was said to have remained emotionless as the verdict was read out.

Advertisement

The jackpot was paid to Putman just before the six-month deadline for claims expired.

Camelot had verified the ticket as genuine, allowing him collect £2,525,485.

The money has still not been recovered with the Crown Prosecution Service saying it would ‘take steps to recover his fraudulently acquired winnings’.

Knibbs, who worked for the company’s fraud detection department in Watford between 2004 and 2010 was the mastermind behind the scam, having figured out a way to cheat the system.

Prosecutor James Keeley said the fraud was only discovered, when Knibbs, of Bricket Wood, Hertfordshire, killed himself at Ivinghoe Beacon in Buckinghamshire, on October 5, 2015.

Giles Knibbs killed himself three days before he was due in court

The court heard that Knibbs confronted Putman in a heated argument in June 2015 believing he was due a £1m share of the prize.

He then broke Putman’s wing mirrors and stole his phone, and was subsequently arrested for burglary, blackmail and criminal damage after Putman complained to police.

He later killed himself after fearing he would go down for ’10 to 15 years for blackmail’, the trial heard.

Evidence suggested Mr Knibbs was initially paid £280,000 by Putman for his part, followed by smaller increments totalling £50,000.

He would take his own life three days before he was due in court in October last year.

Putman tried to hide his identity on his way to court (Picture: Hyde News & Pictures Ltd)

Mr Keeley said: ‘On any view, Mr Knibbs felt that the defendant had treated him unjustly. It was this sense of injustice that came to a head in June 2015.’

Advertisement

He said the March 11 jackpot draw remained unclaimed, but 170 days after the draw and just 10 days before the winning ticket was due to expire, Putman called Camelot claiming he held the winning ticket.

Olympian's PA apologises after video proves driver she accused did not endanger cyclist

The prosecutor added: ‘He was lying. He did not hold the winning tricked, but a forgery created by Mr Knibbs.’

Passing sentence, judge Philip Grey said the ‘sophisticated, carefully planned, and diligently operated fraud’ struck at the heart of the integrity of the National Lottery.

He said: ‘You would have got away with this but quite plainly you were greedy.

Putman’s ‘winnings’ have yet to be recovered (Picture: PA Wire)

‘Whatever the exact monetary split you and Mr Knibbs had agreed, you did not pay him what split he felt he was owed. The two of you fell out spectacularly.

‘This crime struck at the integrity of the National Lottery. You have also undermined the public’s trust in the lottery itself.’

Boy, 3, with autism thrown out of shop for having assistance dog

Despite his windfall Putman would later be sentenced, in 2012, to nine months for benefit fraud after claiming £13,000 welfare support, while splashing out on sports cars and a new house.

His previous convictions also include the rape of a teenager in the early 1990s, for which he was sentenced to seven years.

A Camelot spokesman said the matter was a ‘unique, one-off incident over a decade ago’.

He added: ‘There were some weaknesses in some of the specific controls relevant to this incident at the time and we’re very sorry for that.

Advertisement

‘We’ve strengthened our processes significantly since then and are completely confident that an incident of this nature could not happen today.’
